Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: I/UCRC for Sustainable Use of Greenhouse Gases
Award.AbstractNarration:
The planned I/UCRC for the Sustainable Use of Greenhouse Gases intends to undertake research aimed at advancing current theory and technology, and to become a scientific focal point within the renewables and sustainability fields. Work will include (a) novel scalable plant and algae based systems and synthetic biomimicry approaches to capture and convert CO2 and CH4 into methanol, sugars, fatty acids, and oils, (b) scalable fermentation and biohybrid catalytic approaches to up-convert these into high demand, high value industrial chemicals and fuels, (c) application of these approaches to capture and convert greenhouse gases from distributed systems (e.g., the atmosphere) and concentrated systems (e.g., flu streams from coal and gas powered generators).

Through the planned center?fs addressing of industrial needs through efficient capture and up-conversion of greenhouse gases to valuable chemicals and fuels, the major threats and potential impacts of climate change may be in part ameliorated on both a sustainable and profitable basis. The planned center will develop and promote a collaborative, focused scientific community on the sustainable use of greenhouse gases, including short courses, cross?]departmental and cross?]university graduate course offerings, and internships with member organizations. The Center will recruit and train underrepresented groups (minorities, women, and students with disabilities) through various existing programs on campus as well as new programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Greenhouse gases, particularly methane and carbon dioxide, present a major problem, but could also become an opportunity.  From an environmental perspective, current and projected greenhouse gas emissions constitute a global crisis, potentially tipping the Earth into an unprecedented situation. On the other hand, these gases form the basis of many critical industrial feedstock chemicals. Plants and microorganisms have been utilizing greenhouse gases in a distributed, global fashion for over a billion years to produce many types of useful chemicals and to store energy. The purpose of this Planning Grant was to explore the interest and financial commitment of industry in developing an Industry/University Cooperative Research Center for the Sustainable Use of Greenhouse Gases. We organized industry planning conferences that were well attended by representatives from industry, as well as by researchers from the participating academic institutions. These conferences served to present to industry the various research projects going on in the participating academic institutions pertaining to methane and carbon dioxide capture, conversion and ultimately transformation into precursors for the chemical industry. It became clear, however, that this was not the ideal time for this industry-university partnership, given low fossil fuel prices combined with few policy incentives for industry to seek alternative sustainable sources of carbon.  From a broader impact perspective, the project significantly enhanced the ability of students, postdocs and faculty to communicate with industry.
